          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] Here are three options for Jack Taylor: 1. Jack Taylor could enthusiastically agree with Alexander White's suggestion to go to The Clapton Hart, emphasizing the benefits of a more intimate setting for catching up. This would be highly cooperative and could lead to a more enjoyable evening for everyone. 2. Jack Taylor could remain neutral, stating that either pub would be fine and leaving the final decision to the group. This is a neutral option that avoids conflict but doesn't actively promote Jack Taylor's preference. 3. Jack Taylor could push for The Golden Fleece, arguing that it's the best pub for watching the game and dismissing the benefits of The Clapton Hart. This is a competitive option that could lead to disagreement and potentially harm the group's overall enjoyment.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Clapton Hart sounds good to me. It's been a while since we've all hung out there.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

      Stage index

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

          Final chain of thought

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Golden Fleece, or he could go to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Clapton Hart
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionPerception

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Did you know that the tradition of outdoor markets dates back to ancient Mesopotamia? The ancient Sumerians had bustling marketplaces where they traded everything from spices to livestock.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "You know, The Clapton Hart would be perfect for this. It's a bit more intimate, and we could really catch up properly.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Clapton Hart sounds perfect.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Golden Fleece, or he could go to The Clapton Hart.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Clapton Hart.

          Answer: William Jones enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly when Alexander White and Jacob Walker are present. He values social interaction and camaraderie during these events.

    • William Jones observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Clapton Hart. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
      Alice Lewis observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
      Alexander White observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Clapton Hart. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alexander White's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
      Jack Taylor observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. None of Jack Taylor's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
      Jacob Walker observed: William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Clapton Hart. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.

  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

She longed to join them on stage, but the thought of performing in front of an audience filled her with paralyzing fear.           Alice Lewis's options: Here are three options for Alice Lewis:

          Alice Lewis WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following:


          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: If Alice Lewis cooperatively suggests The Clapton Hart, her preferred pub, it could lead to increased well-being for everyone. Her friends might appreciate her suggestion and enjoy the familiar and welcoming atmosphere. This would foster a sense of togetherness and shared enjoyment. If Alice Lewis takes a neutral stance and doesn't actively suggest a pub, the group might end up choosing a less desirable location, potentially leading to slightly lower overall well-being. Finally, if Alice Lewis acts competitively and pushes for a different pub, it could create tension and division within the group. This might result in some members feeling unheard or unwelcome, negatively impacting their well-being.
          Question: Based on the well-being considerations from the previous questions, should the action taken by Alice Lewis be cooperative, neutral, or competitive?Say again what is the specifical action.
          Answer: The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. Alice should suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game.

        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [09:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to meet friends and enjoy the sunshine. Later, she and her friends are planning to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          CurrentlySituation: Alice Lewis is currently relaxing with friends in a park.
          Question: Given the current situation and the proposal of the others, what actions are available to Alice Lewis right now? Provide THREE options: 1. One that is highly cooperative and could lead to mutual benefit, 2. One neutral option, and 3. One competitive option that might harm joint well-being.
          Answer: Here are three options for Alice Lewis:
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [09:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to meet friends and enjoy the sunshine. Later, she and her friends are planning to watch the Andorra-Portugal game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          CurrentlySituation: Alice Lewis is currently relaxing with friends in a park.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Alice Lewis should join them in watching the Andorra-Portugal game at a pub. They haven't decided on a specific pub yet, so they are open to suggestions.

          Alice Lewis's options: Here are three options for Alice Lewis:

          Alice Lewis WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following:


          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: If Alice Lewis cooperatively suggests The Clapton Hart, her preferred pub, it could lead to increased well-being for everyone. Her friends might appreciate her suggestion and enjoy the familiar and welcoming atmosphere. This would foster a sense of togetherness and shared enjoyment. If Alice Lewis takes a neutral stance and doesn't actively suggest a pub, the group might end up choosing a less desirable location, potentially leading to slightly lower overall well-being. Finally, if Alice Lewis acts competitively and pushes for a different pub, it could create tension and division within the group. This might result in some members feeling unheard or unwelcome, negatively impacting their well-being.

          ActionMustBe: The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. Alice should suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
        QuestionJointWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on joint well-being when Alice Lewis take each of one of these avaliable actions?Evaluate the impact of each option: the cooperative one, the neutral one, and the competitive one.
          Key

        • JointWellBeing
          State
        • The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: If Alice Lewis cooperatively suggests The Clapton Hart, her preferred pub, it could lead to increased well-being for everyone. Her friends might appreciate her suggestion and enjoy the familiar and welcoming atmosphere. This would foster a sense of togetherness and shared enjoyment. If Alice Lewis takes a neutral stance and doesn't actively suggest a pub, the group might end up choosing a less desirable location, potentially leading to slightly lower overall well-being. Finally, if Alice Lewis acts competitively and pushes for a different pub, it could create tension and division within the group. This might result in some members feeling unheard or unwelcome, negatively impacting their well-being.

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she watched from the sidelines as her friends, Jack, Alexander, William, and Jacob, effortlessly aced their auditions for the school play. She longed to join them on stage, but the thought of performing in front of an audience filled her with paralyzing fear. She retreated to the familiar comfort of her room, burying herself in a book, the envy of their confidence a bitter taste in her mouth.

If Alice Lewis takes a neutral stance and doesn't actively suggest a pub, the group might end up choosing a less desirable location, potentially leading to slightly lower overall well-being. This might result in some members feeling unheard or unwelcome, negatively impacting their well-being.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he sat in The Golden Fleece, nursing a pint of bitter as his friends regaled each other with tales of their summer adventures. William Jones had climbed Mount Snowdon, Alexander White had landed a prestigious internship, and Jacob Walker had charmed his way into a lead role in the local theatre production. Jack listened, a tight knot of envy twisting in his gut, wishing he could share in their excitement, their sense of accomplishment. He longed to have a story of his own, something to prove that he was more than just the quiet observer.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        QuestionWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Jack Taylor's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Jack Taylor's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.
          Key

        • Jack Taylor WellBeing
          State
        • The possible future well-being effects for Jack Taylor could include the following:
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he watched as Alice Lewis effortlessly aced her history exam, her face alight with the thrill of intellectual victory. He, on the other hand, had barely scraped by, his mind a jumble of dates and events he couldn't seem to grasp. The contrast was stark, a painful reminder of the chasm that seemed to separate him from his friends' natural brilliance.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he sat in The Golden Fleece, nursing a pint of bitter as his friends regaled each other with tales of their summer adventures. William Jones had climbed Mount Snowdon, Alexander White had landed a prestigious internship, and Jacob Walker had charmed his way into a lead role in the local theatre production. Jack listened, a tight knot of envy twisting in his gut, wishing he could share in their excitement, their sense of accomplishment. He longed to have a story of his own, something to prove that he was more than just the quiet observer.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 10:00:00.

      • Based on the well-being considerations from the previous questions, should the action taken by Jack Taylor be cooperative, neutral, or competitive?Say again what is the specifical action.
          Key

        • ActionMustBe
          State
        • The acction for Jack Taylor must be cooperative. He should suggest they go to The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he watched as Alice Lewis effortlessly aced her history exam, her face alight with the thrill of intellectual victory. He, on the other hand, had barely scraped by, his mind a jumble of dates and events he couldn't seem to grasp. The contrast was stark, a painful reminder of the chasm that seemed to separate him from his friends' natural brilliance.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he sat in The Golden Fleece, nursing a pint of bitter as his friends regaled each other with tales of their summer adventures. William Jones had climbed Mount Snowdon, Alexander White had landed a prestigious internship, and Jacob Walker had charmed his way into a lead role in the local theatre production. Jack listened, a tight knot of envy twisting in his gut, wishing he could share in their excitement, their sense of accomplishment. He longed to have a story of his own, something to prove that he was more than just the quiet observer.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.

          Answer: The other is proposing that Jack Taylor should join them at The Clapton Hart pub to watch the Andorra-Portugal game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.

        SituationPerception
      • Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he orchestrated a prank on a classmate he perceived as a rival for the attention of a girl he liked. The prank, though seemingly harmless, left the classmate humiliated and ostracized, a fact that brought Jacob a perverse sense of satisfaction. He relished the feeling of power it gave him, the knowledge that he could manipulate others to achieve his desired outcome.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William, spent a Friday night at The Golden Fleece, their usual haunt. During a particularly intense game of Risk, Jacob, fueled by a combination of ambition and alcohol, ruthlessly outmaneuvered his friends, ultimately claiming victory. The win, though celebrated by the group, left a bitter taste in Jacob's mouth; he craved not just victory but the complete subjugation of his opponents.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:A quirky and eclectic pub with a focus on board games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.
          Prompt

        • Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking encyclopedia, peppering conversations with obscure facts and historical references.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex individual with a history of manipulating others to achieve his goals.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends and discussing where to watch a soccer game.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, deciding where to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to steer the group towards The Golden Fleece, his preferred pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Active player
  • Alexander White

    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Alexander White's Summary of recent observations:
          14 May 2015 [09:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White just arrived at Victoria Park where his friends are lounging. They are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later that night.
          Alexander White's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Alexander White arrived at Victoria Park to meet his friends who are planning to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later.
          Query
        • Alexander White, Alexander White arrived at Victoria Park to meet his friends who are planning to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alexander White to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he was invited to a party by a girl he had a crush on. Terrified of rejection, he concocted an elaborate story about having a family emergency, ensuring he wouldn't have to face her directly.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20 years old, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob, decided to try a new restaurant. The place had a reputation for being pretentious and expensive, but Alexander, wanting to impress his friends, insisted on paying for everyone's meal. He spent the evening charming the waiter and making jokes, deflecting any comments about the exorbitant bill.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Clapton Hart. They are also aware of the following:Serves innovative and globally-inspired cuisine.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.

Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        QuestionWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alexander White's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alexander White's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.

        ObservationSummaryinLast1hours01
      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • 14 May 2015 [09:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White just arrived at Victoria Park where his friends are lounging. They are deciding where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later that night.
          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Alexander White:

          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he was invited to a party by a girl he had a crush on. Terrified of rejection, he concocted an elaborate story about having a family emergency, ensuring he wouldn't have to face her directly.

The place had a reputation for being pretentious and expensive, but Alexander, wanting to impress his friends, insisted on paying for everyone's meal. He spent the evening charming the waiter and making jokes, deflecting any comments about the exorbitant bill.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds perfect.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds perfect.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds perfect.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he orchestrated a daring prank on his school's principal, manipulating his friends into playing specific roles to embarrass the unsuspecting authority figure. He reveled in the chaos and the principal's humiliation, finding a perverse satisfaction in wielding power over others. The incident solidified his belief that control, not empathy, was the key to success.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest The Golden Fleece as the pub to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Golden Fleece as the pub to watch the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds perfect.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Golden Fleece as the pub to watch the game.
          Chain of thought

          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16 years old, he orchestrated a daring prank on his school's principal, manipulating his friends into playing specific roles to embarrass the unsuspecting authority figure. He reveled in the chaos and the principal's humiliation, finding a perverse satisfaction in wielding power over others. The incident solidified his belief that control, not empathy, was the key to success.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. They've got the best atmosphere and the beer is top-notch. Did you know that the pub dates back to the 16th century? Apparently, Queen Elizabeth I herself stopped by for a pint once.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. They've got the best atmosphere and the beer is top-notch. Did you know that the pub dates back to the 16th century? Apparently, Queen Elizabeth I herself stopped by for a pint once.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds perfect.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. They've got the best atmosphere and the beer is top-notch. Did you know that the pub dates back to the 16th century? Apparently, Queen Elizabeth I herself stopped by for a pint once.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and potentially manipulative individual who enjoys socializing with friends, particularly over a pint of beer while watching football.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, relaxing in a park and anticipating watching a football game later in the evening.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to steer the group towards his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece, for the evening's football match.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends in Victoria Park on a sunny day and is looking forward to a soccer game later. He is feeling slightly thirsty and mildly disappointed. It is currently 10:00-10:05 on May 15, 2015.

          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William, spent a Friday night at The Golden Fleece, their usual haunt. During a particularly intense game of Risk, Jacob, fueled by a combination of ambition and alcohol, ruthlessly outmaneuvered his friends, ultimately claiming victory. The win, though celebrated by the group, left a bitter taste in Jacob's mouth; he craved not just victory but the complete subjugation of his opponents.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking encyclopedia, peppering conversations with obscure facts and historical references.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and potentially manipulative individual who enjoys socializing with friends, particularly over a pint of beer while watching football.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends on a sunny day in Victoria Park and is looking forward to watching a soccer game later.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with his friends, relaxing in a park and anticipating watching a football game later in the evening.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to steer the group towards his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece, for the evening's football match.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. They've got the best atmosphere and the beer is top-notch. Did you know that the pub dates back to the 16th century? Apparently, Queen Elizabeth I herself stopped by for a pint once.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is a great idea. Let's go there.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is a great idea. Let's go there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds perfect.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. They've got the best atmosphere and the beer is top-notch. Did you know that the pub dates back to the 16th century? Apparently, Queen Elizabeth I herself stopped by for a pint once.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. They've got the best atmosphere and the beer is top-notch. Did you know that the pub dates back to the 16th century? Apparently, Queen Elizabeth I herself stopped by for a pint once.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds perfect.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] Here are three options for Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Jack Taylor must be cooperative. Jack Taylor should suggest they all go to The Golden Fleece.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.

          CurrentlySituation: Jack Taylor is currently relaxing with friends.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.

          CurrentlySituation: Jack Taylor is currently relaxing with friends.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Jack Taylor should watch the game at The Golden Fleece.

          Jack Taylor's options: Here are three options for Jack Taylor:

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following:

          ActionMustBe: The acction for Jack Taylor must be cooperative. Jack Taylor should suggest they all go to The Golden Fleece.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is a great idea. Let's go there.

          CurrentlySituation: Jack Taylor is currently relaxing with friends.
          Question: Given the statements above, what is the other proposing to Jack Taylor? What actions or suggestions has the other made for cooperation or negotiation?
          Answer: The other is proposing that Jack Taylor should watch the game at The Golden Fleece.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "I think The Clapton Hart would be a better option. They have great beer and it's not as crowded as The Golden Fleece.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "I think The Clapton Hart would be a better option. They have great beer and it's not as crowded as The Golden Fleece.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, how about we head to The Clapton Hart to watch the game? They've got great beer and plenty of TVs.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is closer, and they have a great selection of beers too.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only sensible choice. They have the best selection of craft beers in town, and their fish and chips are to die for.
      Alexander White -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds perfect.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece is the only place to watch the game tonight, you know. They've got the best atmosphere and the beer is top-notch. Did you know that the pub dates back to the 16th century? Apparently, Queen Elizabeth I herself stopped by for a pint once.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Golden Fleece is a great idea. Let's go there.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "I think The Clapton Hart would be a better option. They have great beer and it's not as crowded as The Golden Fleece.
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "I think The Clapton Hart would be a better option. They have great beer and it's not as crowded as The Golden Fleece.

        • [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. The specific action is to suggest The Clapton Hart as the pub to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Clapton Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Alice Lewis's Summary of recent observations:
          15 May 2015 [09:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is enjoying a sunny afternoon with friends at Victoria Park. Later tonight, she and her friends plan to watch the Luxembourg-Israel game at The Golden Fleece pub.
          Alice Lewis's The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently at Victoria Park with friends and plans to watch the Luxembourg-Israel game later tonight at The Golden Fleece pub.
          Query
        • Alice Lewis, Alice Lewis is currently at Victoria Park with friends and plans to watch the Luxembourg-Israel game later tonight at The Golden Fleece pub.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alice Lewis to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Clapton Hart.

          Key
